38891226.review:
Superflight is amazing for what it is. It captures the feel of "falling with style" quite well and the maps are usually great and not buggy. 
However there is one annoying problem that other games like this one also suffer from. A problem that will mostly effect casual players that pay $3 and expect just a relaxing, distracting game.

After you become half decent (about 5 minutes of play will get you there), the game becomes waaay too long. For a casual and relaxing game to have "runs", the runs need to be short (10 minutes tops). However you can really just go on and on forever. There is no real change in difficulty and the only challenge comes from how daring and greedy you get with combos. That means unless you like to constantly crash into things every minute, the game becomes way too easy and boring.

It's a problem worth not recommending over because games like Superflight need to be short, sweet and relaxing. Not long, boring and repetitive.

It really is unfortunate that I feel the need to make this review since I would have expected other reviews to mention this problem. But nope, it's all praise and regurgitating the game's steam description -_-
I realise that writing a negative review on a game with an Overwhelmingly Positive rating is probably futile, but just in case someone reads this it might be worth it.







EDIT: seeing how the dev's are actually responding to some reviews, I guess all I could recommend is something to spice up the gameplay and difficulty (preferably optional). 

Like for example some maps give more points but are windier or have lesser/greater gravity. Another idea is if some of the maps generated could have goals of some kind (outside of points). Like say you could try to figure out how to get to the center and when you do you teleport with a permanent  x1.5 multiplier. Off the top of my head the only other idea I have is seeing a ghost of yourself from a previous run fly with you. It could be cool since if you use the same routes enough it might look like you are a flock of birds or something. It wouldn't make the game more difficult but it would add another element to the replayability.

I honestly can't really think of a good solution since anything too crazy could be asking too much for a game that is so cheap and only developed by a few people.

38868108.review:
While very simple, Superflight accomplishes what it sets out to do - provide a relaxing experience based on gliding down procedurally generated levels with the goal of earning as many points possible during your run (which ends upon crashing into a solid surface). Points are earned based mostly on sticking close to surfaces. There are potential moments of intensity, but those only come if you decide to slip into narrow holes for increased points. The game is also very simple to control and may be something you let younger kids play around with (I imagine my nephews would enjoy it).

My only complaints are that there doesn't seem to be a way to view the full leaderboard (you can see your ranking based on your top score and top combo) and the weird 'click' noise when you hit play and start a run (it just annoys me).

If you enjoy having a game to play while doing something else (like listening to music, podcasts, etc.) or enjoy trying to continuously beat your high score, I highly recommend it, especially for the current sale price of $1.49.

38849897.review:
Superflight. 
Descubrí este juego por mera casualidad, un par de segundos de Gameplay en una compilación de juegos en Youtube. Sólo me bastó eso, un par de segundos. El juego me atrajo de una manera que pocos otros me han atraído. Sus escenarios, cuadrados, y preciosos. 
Su temática, la de cualquier juego arcade. Pero este juego es otra cosa. Es más que un par de cubos, más que un par de puntos. Tú controlas tu velocidad, tú controlas tu altura. Tú controlas el recorrido, y hay miles. Y miles de mapas con otros miles de recovecos por donde meterse. En definitiva, tú decides cómo conseguir tus puntos. Si prefieres ir tranquilo, rozando las paredes pero sin mucho peligro, puedes. Y si eres de los que les gusta el riesgo, meterte por cada hueco, y descubrir si tiene salida, también puedes. Además, si sólo te apetece dar un vistazo por todos los mapas posibles sin cambiar de partida, hazlo. Sólo busca portales o cae en picado hasta llegar a otro mapa. Eso es cosa tuya. 
Es un juego relajante, pero tienes que estar alerta. Con un poco de buena música para acompañar al juego, pueden darte las tantas. Los obstáculos son previsibles, pero hay que saber evitarlos. Es tan simple que asusta, pero tan complejo, que gusta. Un cúmulo de sensaciones que merecen la pena vivir, aunque sea por un rato. El juego lo vale. Lo recomiendo bastante a cualquiera que lea esto.

38824353.review:
[h1]O Jogo[/h1]
 [b]Superflight[/b] foi desenvolvido e publicado pela [b]GrizzlyGames[/b] e a proposta do jogo é voar e subir no rank do jogo.

[h1]Objetivo[/h1]
 O objetivo do jogo é voar e fazer manobras que o da pontos para subir sua pontuação no rank. Outra maneira de ganhar pontos é entrando em portais, que lhe concedem 1000 pontos e o levam para outro mapa. Outra forma de ir para outro mapa é descendo o mais baixo possível.

[h1]Localização[/h1]
 O jogo não possui tradução mas isso não atrapalhará muito sua jogatina.

[h1]Trilha Sonora[/h1]
 O jogo simplesmente não possui trilha sonora, na verdade os únicos sons são do vento e da batida(quando você morre)

[h1]Gráficos[/h1]
 O jogo apostou em gráficos simples e minimalistas, e acertaram, os gráficos do jogo são ótimos

[h1]Conclusão[/h1]
 O jogo é simples, divertido, bonito e relaxante, ótimo para quando se está estressado

[h1]Pontos Positivos[/h1]
[list]
 [*]Cenários simples e bonitos
 [*]Boa jogabilidade
 [*]Conquistas desafiadoras
 [*]Classificação steam
 [*]Divertido e relaxante
 [*]Preço acessível 
[/list]

[h1]Pontos Negativos[/h1]
[list]
 [*]Não possui trilha sonora
[/list]

[h1]Avaliação Final[/h1]
[list]
 [*]Gráfico[b] 8.8[/b]
 [*]Jogabilidade[b] 9.0[/b]
 [*]Desafio[b] 7.6[/b]
 [*]Trilha Sonora[b] 0.1[/b]
 [*]Diversão[b] 8.9[/b]
 [*]Nota Final[b] 7.8[/b]
[/list]

小学校の工作の授業で作ったみたいなキャラで滑空するゲーム。
地形ギリギリを攻めるほど高い得点を得られ、ニアミスするとボーナス。

38769806.review:
A truely amazing experience.

'Superflight' is one of those titles that you stumble on which then go on to become a staple of you daily consumption.
early on, it's clear that each map is unique and every one promotes a sense of exploration (to the point it's really difficult to have a 'safe run' - you may start out with the calmest intentions, but those gaps are sooo very inviting)

The sense of risk/reward is foremost in your mind whilst playing and for the strong minded there is a game of two beautiful extremes (a score chasing daredevil session or a meditative, Zen like experience) both have their place, but I find I am best served when I utilise a composite of the two styles.

The seed system deserves mention: Within the 'Maps' option, you can type a word/sentence to generate a unique map which also allows you to share them with other people. Any currently loaded map can be saved too, allowing convenient access to the many fantastic maps you will discover while in flight.

On paper, it all sounds very simple and unimpressive, but it really is more than the sum of it's parts.
I strongly recommend 'Superflight' without reservation, it's a really well put together package, with a simply beautiful asthetic, glorious sound design, tight controls and unlimited enviroments to discover, explore (and share)
I bought this on sale and now feel guilty (that rarely happens) so I will be buying a copy or two for gifting once the current sale ends.

 (full price purchase recommended)  10/10 (and a gold star)   :approved:

One of those games you buy expecting to play occasionally to chill out - and next thing you know its 4 hours later because you keep hitting replay.

[u]Gameplay[/u]

Basically a wingsuit game with random levels, where you try to come as close to dying as possible without ACTUALLY dying. Closer to death, more points you get. Portals to other levels exist on every level, or fly down far enough and you go to another random level.

It sounds so simple, but it's really addictive and fun. Highly recommend you buy it, put on some of your favorite music, and just fly around!

38758980.review:
Fantastic little game, so much fun, great for when your watching a movie on a second monitor or something, its that perfect mix of relaxing at times, heart pounding at others.
I think what makes this really fun is its simplicity. Aside from the score system, there isnt really any progression. Now in most games, this might be considered a bad thing, but in Superflight its the opposite. Without the progression system that most games with similar mechanics have, you have nothing to lose from taking crazy risks. You wont lose your plane you grinded 3 hours for, if you die you just try it again. And thats what makes it so fun, its all about doing quick tricks and challenging yourself to do something so crazy that it just might work. Exactly what I've been looking for.

This game is well made. 
What do I mean by that? Well, as the devs are honest enough to tell you, this isn't a long, grindy game that you'll play for hours at a time, this is a simple, carefree game. It doesn't do much, but it never promises anything more than what it has. Everything in the game is clean, polished, and neat.
[b] What Superflight does, it does very well. [/b]
This is a different game, this game doesn't limit what you can do based on balance or PvP ques, instead, you simply fly, crash, and fly again. Why? not to get a better flight suit, not to watch a currency number go up, simply because [i] it's fun and you want to. [/i]

Definitely recommended, it's just easy and fun.

38694242.review:
This is a minimalist wingsuit game made in Unity. Bought on a whim during the 2017 Winter Sale, I had a lot more fun with this game than I expected. Within the first few minutes I knew I was going to like it.  Every map is procedurally generated and feels different & unique albeit rather small considering the player speed. The objective is to get the highest score and to do that you need to fly close to walls & objects as long as you can to build speed and a score combo/multiplier. As it tracks your highscore you can climb the online leaderboards and earn achievements. There's no music but that's okay, it's better if you put on your own anyway.

 If I had to nitpick or complain about it, the list would be small. It lacks a first person view mode and lacks accessibility when it comes to choosing which analog stick to use. The Dev should definitley include those options. Even a VR mode for those who want it would be welcome.

Not much else to it. As the description says it's simplistic and can be intense or relaxing depending on how you wanna fly through the maps. I paid $1.49 and I'd say it's worth it. Even would be worth it at the normal $3 price if you can really get into it.

Great little game.  It's one of those games you play to burn 5-10 minutes.  Has that "ONE MORE TIME!" sorta arcadey feel to it.  This is loosely like that "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA" game be Dejoban games, but you have a bit more control on your fall and you have the ability to fly upwards if you're careful.

Very simple premise - rack up as high of a score as possible by paragliding as close to the edges of cliffs and walls and holes without crashing.  Chain together these glides for more points.  Take portals to generate new maps and gain more points and just keep doing it over and over again.  If you're looking at this during the Steam sale, buy it.  Worth the money.

38671378.review:
遊んでいるうちに、
空を飛んでいるのか
空を堕ちているのか
わからなくなってくる。



そんなゲーム。




このゲームは
キーボードの十字キーをつかって
滑空する疑似体験ができる、
シミュレーターのようなゲームだ。



障害物スレスレを飛んだり、
物と物の隙間を上手くクグり抜けたりすると
得点を稼ぐことができる。



また、ステージはランダム生成で、
一番下まで行くか横端まで行くか
ポータルに入ると別のステージにワープする。



以上の繰り返しがこのゲームの全てだ。




このゲームの最大の魅力は
何と言っても”風の音”だろう。




壁のギリギリを飛び抜ける時の轟音や
耳元でささやくような風切音は、
日常では味わえない
グライドの魅力的な時間を提供してくれる。



また、ZENモードを選ぶと
得点獲得SEが鳴らなくなるので、
文字通り飛行に没頭する
”禅”状態を楽しむことができる。




ゲームに目的はないので、
非日常的な体験をしながら
ハイスコアを狙ってみるのも良いだろう。

38668225.review:
[quote]What we would like to offer you is a simple game that gives you the feeling of intense speed, high adrenaline moments and beautiful vistas to explore at the price of a coffee to go.[/quote]

This game hits on that exact desire perfectly. After hearing heaps of praise for the game, and seeing the minimal entry fee, I decided to pick it up. I died. And then I started over, dying again, and again, but learning from my mistakes. As I hit the achievement for dying 300 times in a span of roughly 80 minutes, not once did I regret any of those 300 retries. It is a game where you perfect a line, gliding through tunnels and avoiding crashing and racking up a score that puts your friends to shame.

I anticipate that the game will continue to be supported and hopefully have little updates here and there, but honestly even at $3 normally, this game is well worth it. Visually, and addictingly, I feel like it is in the same vein as Refunt, which is easy to play for quick bursts. Honestly, this is one of the hidden (hopefully not for long, it deserves to be played) gems of the Winter 2017 sale.

38664035.review:
(Soar)
(twist)
(twist)
(dive)
Crash.
Play again.
(soar)
(twist)
(dive)
(twist)
(soar)
(dive}
(twist)
Crash.
New map.
Play again.
(soar)
(soar)
(twist)
(dive)
(dive)
(dive)
(twist)
(soar)
(twist)
Crash.
Sigh.

Repeat.
Die.
Repeat.

I like playing this for short periods, because that's all I ever get. I really, REALLY wish it had a slow (or even a guided camera) mode so I could do it more leisurely and explore things. In slow mode, I could explore those amazing maps more thoroughly. As it this, they whizz past, blurred features I barely see, inviting me to plunge into them. Which I do. Often. Every time, in fact.

And it needs a function ro remap the keys for those of us with awkward hands or keyboard layouts. 

I have the horizontal and vertical sensitivity cranked to max and it's not enough to keep me afloat for very long. Soaring upwards always seems abrupt and always ends in a precipitous dive immediately after. I wish I could have more control over the rates and speeds of movement. Or maybe an option for updrafts or to change gravity.

You can create some astounding-looking maps, but I never see them for more than a few seconds. My top score ranks at the bottom of thouands of other players. 

Still, it's impressive for the price. I look forward to seeing where it goes next and hope some of my suggestions get serious consideration.

Sonunda değişik bir oyun ama ne yazık ki tadımlık...

Uzun zamandır denk gelmediğim basit ama yaratıcı fikirlerden biri Superflight. İyice basite indirgersek havadan süzülme oyunu denilebilir. Tıpkı Just Cause 3' te olduğu gibi ama o kadar iyi mekaniklere mi sahip oyun tartışılır. 

"Let' s Play!" tarzında bir oyun oluşu nedeniyle sanmıyorum ki biraz hırs ve vakit geçirmeden sonra oyunun yüzüne bakasınız. Engellere sıyırttırarak(Çarpmadan) yüksek hızlarda geçerek skor kasıp rekora oynamak amaç. İşte bu nedenle biraz ilgilenip daha sonra yüzüne bakmayacağınız bir oyun dedim. Ama "Ağzımın tadı değişsin birazcık." diyorsanız tavsiye ederim.  Şu andaki %50 indirimli fiyatıyla yani 3,10 TL' ye alınabilecek kötü bir oyun değil.

Unutmadan; oyun içerisinde tamamen aşağı doğru düşerken bir anda oyunda kafanızı yukarıya doğru kaldırmaya çalışmanız ile oyun bir anda sapıtıyor. Yüksekten atladığınızı varsayın dimdik aşağıya bakarak giderken bir anda düz bir şekilde inmeye çalışıyorsunuz. Hava, siz bunu yaparken engel bir kuvvet uygulayacak doğal olarak ama oyunda bu düzgün yapılamamış ve doğru dürüst manevralar alamıyorsunuz. Yani oyunun süzülme üzerine kurulu olması gerekirken siz havayı delmeye çalışıyorsunuz tam tabiri ile...

Dediğim gibi bunlara rağmen uygun fiyatlı oluşu ile fena bir oyun değil. Devil Daggers oyununa da göz gezdirebilirsiniz aynı şekilde "Let' s Play!" türü bir oyun. O da belki ağzınızın tadını değiştirir kim bilir.

I believe that this game has immense potential.

I love the way the developers marketed their game as tranquil and relaxing, however I disagree. The game is extremely fun, but also immensely high-paced, and in the case, not relaxing in the slightest. I do however still enjoy the game, but not for the included "relaxation" factor supposedly included in its package. I would also like to see certain impovements to the game in the controls. It would make the game a lot more fun and less frustrating if you had the option to either use the mouse or designate your own keys. In total, the game just needs to be more flexible to the needs of the gamers control wise, because we all play differently.

Overall I enjoy the game, but it did not deliver what was promised in my opinion for the "tranquil" and "scerene" feel the developers advertised. Howver, the game is extremely cheap for the amount of fun I had, so it deserves a sold 9/10.

38553379.review:
In Superflight steuert ihr einen Typen mit einer Art Wingsuit durch zufallsgenerierte Welten und versucht dabei möglichst viele Punkte zu erzielen, indem ihr nahe an Wänden oder an Böden vorbeifliegt und durch Lücken und Löcher durchschießt. 
Mit diesem Satz lässt sich dieses Spiel ganz gut zusammenfassen. 
Es kostet je nachdem ob im Sale oder nicht, einen Burger bei McDonalds oder ein Bier aus dem Automaten und daran will ich dieses kleine Indie-Game gerne messen.
Für diesen Preis bietet Superflight ein tolles Geschwindigkeitsgefühl, eine einfache aber eindrucksvolle Optik, eine griffige Steuerung mit dem Controller und somit insgesamt ein schönes Spielkonzept für zwischendurch, denn Langzeitmotivation wird wahrscheinlich nur bei denen aufkommen, die Platz 1 im Globalen Highscore werden wollen. 
Einziger Kritikpunkt von meiner Seite betrifft den fehlenden Soundtrack, irgendetwas was den Spielflow unterstützt, wäre cool gewesen.

Bewertung: Ich gebe dem Spiel 8 von 10 Punkten.

38514980.review:
It isn't often I'm impressed by a title enough that I make the effort to write anything about it, let alone praise it. 

Superflight is an incredibly simple game. You fly around, preferably as close to objects as possible, and you rack up points. It is very reminiscint of the "oncoming" bonus from Burnout where you'd rack up extra boost for driving against traffic and between cars.  Despite the mechanics themselves, Superflight is a very relaxing game. While there's a ranking system of sorts and you can compete for high scores, the game doesn't particularly force that aspect on you; the gameplay truly seems to have its focus set on the freedom of flight. Sometimes a game is best defined by what it doesn't have, and minimalism can really bring out the simple beauty of a game or its mechanics; I think this perfectly describes Superflight. 

The sound design for the game is great. My only gripe is that the score sound can be a bit grating, but you can turn it off if you like. There is no music, but the sound of the wind I found very relaxing, actually. 

The controls are a bit flighty, no pun intended. There's a certain floatiness to them, especially on keyboard. I haven't yet tried the game using a controller, however, though that may improve the experience somewhat. Despite this, you can still find yourself pulling off some really neat maneuvers and the game genuinely feels good. 

Procedural generation works pretty well for the level design here, and you can "create" your own levels by entering a seed to use for generation. Maps can also be saved so you can later revisit levels that you'd like to play on again. There appears to be quite a bit of variation in the levels; some with large pillars and small pathways, others with small thin floating walls with holes in the center. It's easy to change maps too, as the game will instantly transport you to the next map if you get to the bottom of the current one, or if you enter a portal. Your score is retained, though you will lose any multiplyer you had built up on the previous map. 

Even for the regular price of 2.99 US I think this game is a great buy. It's the perfect game to de-stress with after work.

38512129.review:
i'll give this game a very weak "recommend".

it's alright for what it is, but the asking price is a bit arguable for something like this, especially considering how many better games are out for the same price (or cheaper, considering the current winter sale).

the gameplay is simple yet addictive. i'll admit that i had a hard time putting it down when i first started playing.

the controls are... eh. not particularly good but not unplayable either.

the graphics look pretty nice, i'll give them that. i'm a sucker for simplicity.

the maps are all just kind of the same thing really, alcoves in randomly generated locations with different textures. the concept of "thousands of maps" is kind of misleading considering they're all basically the same.

the physics are the main thing that can get pretty annoying though. a lot of my deaths have been from my character suddenly deciding to take a nosedive that i couldn't recover from. it feels less like flying and more like... gliding?


get this game on sale if you think it's something you'll really like, but know that you're pretty much just getting what you're seeing. this game deserves praise, but not the kind that it's getting.

38509370.review:
tl;dr: Really enjoyable, among the best out there for this kind of money.

Hop into your minimalistic wingsuit and fly through simple, yet pretty and interesting, procedurally generated scenery. Put on Zen mode and take in the blissful sound of wind, or try hard for the highest score you can get.

What I like most about Superflight, is that even though, at its core, it's a "keep trying and score high" kind of game, you're given a tremendous amount of control and freedom. You don't have to nail a level in order to advance - you can pick whatever path you like, fly it in any way you want, and move on to the next landscape whenever you feel like it.

The controls and flight mechanics are, as advertised, very intuitive. The graphics look good and fit the game like a glove.

It's relaxing, but also challenging - each in the exact proportions that you define for yourself.
It's simple, but captivating.
It's cheap, but so entertaining - you might not believe it cost so little.

A great idea for a simple flight game, BUT.... it suffers from the same problem that All others I've tried such as Altitude-0, Cannot or not enough Keyboard mapping. Not everyone (At Least I Don't) uses WASD for their keyboard settings. I use "ASDF" because WASD Scrunches my fingers into an arrow or pyramid shape which is very unnatural for me. 

And, Yes, I know I can use a controller but I'm NOT going to plug in My Saitek X52 Flight stick for what is supposed to be a "Casual" game.

Being able to use the Mouse for things such as Pitch and Roll, and the Keyboard for Yaw and Throttle would be Optimal for me. I REALLY Hope the Devs can give us mouse control and Keyboard Re-Mapping, because until then I cannot play this game the way I would like. 

I have to give a thumbs down for now but I will Update this review if / when they ever give us more control options.

38404502.review:
Superflight is a wonderful gem of an indie game, coming out of nowhere to make one of the most relaxing and challenging bite-sized games in recent memory.

You play as a little box-man with glider wings strapped to your arms, and the sole purpose is to glide through procedurally-generated environments, racking up the score by flying through gaps and hugging the walls. Each "level" is unique, generated from a random seed, and there are multiple portals strewn throughout each level to take you further. Sometimes you're faced with thin, snowy towering pillars, other times primary-colored floating "mountains" with tiny tunnels carved throughout. There's no way to know where the next portal will bring you, and I still get surprised by some of the different environments I see.

And on the topic of visuals, the minimalist graphics fit the concept perfectly - there's the expected motion blur, AA, and post effects, but they're kept to an appropriate level. It's like Katamari and Journey had a baby that grew up playing Minecraft.
I did encounter some slowdowns when entering new worlds after playing for a while, but I'm not sure if it's a system issue or the game itself - and it would clear up after a short while of flying around.

The ability to generate your own levels based on seeds is a nice touch; try your name, your phone number, etc, and see what kind of world appears as a result. "superflight" gave a nice challenge, and "Zen" was decidedly un-zenlike.

While the time to 100% is short (I was able to do it in about 2 hours), the real enjoyment comes from just playing the game. Whether you want to go for the highest score among your friends, or turn on Zen mode and just glide, Superflight is the perfect antidote to overburdened AAA games flooding the market nowadays.

[h1]PREFAZIONE[/h1]
Prendete Steep. Togliete 55 euro. Togliete la neve. Togliete l'aria da "WHOO, SPORT ESTREMI!".
Aggiungete la generazione casuale dei mondi, una grafica cubettosa, ma molto gradevole, ed avrete SuperFlight.

[h1]RECENSIONE[/h1]
Ho conosciuto questo gioco grazie a [url=www.youtube.com/user/GameSprout]GameSprout[/url]  , nella serie "Gamers Are Awesome", e subito me ne sono innamorato.
È impossibile non notare la somiglianza con [url=www.ubisoft.com/en-us/game/steep/]Steep[/url] , della Ubisoft, ma dal mio punto di vista SuperFlight rinnova la formula cambiandola in meglio.

.exeと同階層に配置されているrelease_noteによれば起稿時点のVer.は1.0.5。ゲームクリアの概念は存在しません。全実績解除まで2時間所要しました。

[h1]Pros:[/h1][list]
[*]空気抵抗を体感できるインゲーム力学
[*]中毒性のあるスコアリングSE
[*]超高速なリトライ[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1][list]
[*]フォグが濃すぎる場合がある
[*]生還できない自動生成パターン[/list]

[h1]高速で壁面スレスレを飛ぶのが超気持ちいい[/h1]

　superflightはウィングスーツで滑空するUnity製の3Dゲーム。タイトル画面でStartを選択するや否や滑空が開始され、壁に激突したら即座にミスとなりタイトル画面へ戻る。壁面近くを通過すればするほど高得点が得られる仕組みとなっており、最終的なスコアをオンライン上のリーダーボードで競い合う。

　ステージの生成は乱数シードを基に自動的に生成される。シード値が同じであれば同じステージが生成されます。訪れたステージは記録しておくことが可能。ステージ内に配置されているピンク色のワープキューブか、ステージ下限判定に接触することで次のステージに進む。ステージは永久的に生成されるため、ミスしない限り終わりはありません。

　壁面スレスレを通過したときの特別ボーナスを得られた場合もそうですが、それ以前に得点が入る際のSEが常時お金が振り込まれているような感覚を覚えて気持ちいいです。最高速に達した際のスクロール速度もかなりのものでこの状態で狭い穴を抜けたときは爽快でカタルシスを得られます。風切り音だけが聞こえてBGMがない点は、かえって聴覚ではなく視覚のみに集中できる効果がある気がします。リトライもワンボタンで行えるのでストレスフリーです。

　残念な点はやはりというか自動生成にまつわる部分。ステージによってはフォグが濃過ぎて前方の穴が視認しづらい場合があり、突入を躊躇う場合が多く感じられました。また外壁が高い壁に覆われているステージ構成の場合、内部に向かうとそれだけで詰むパターンも見られました。自動生成の構築パターンでテクニックは要するが必ずステージ下部または外周まで抜けられるように、ステージ構築されるアルゴリズムとなっていたら良かったのにと感じます。


　本作が制作されたドイツでウィングスーツが流行しているのかどうかは分かりませんが、そのスピード感やエッセンスは感じることができます。プロのスカイダイバーでも500回以上の経験を要するように、ミスしたときのプレイヤーキャラがバラバラに砕け散る様子(グロくはないです)が少し現実を感じさせたりしますが、気付いたらお構いなしにガンガン壁面スレスレを滑空している中毒性があります。310円の定価もあってオススメです。

38362175.review:
[h1]Good:[/h1]
- Great controls
- Nice looking, surreal landscapes to fly through
- Score system + leaderboards
- Easy to learn, difficult to master

[h1]Room for improvement:[/h1]
- levels generate entries and tunnels with dead ends. There is often no way to know when flying in.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Superflight is a delightfully simple concept, and I like it.
You control a character with a wingsuit and you fly through strange surreal landscapes which are randomly generated.
It seems deceptively easy, but make no mistake, this game goes fast and you will crash... a lot.
You will not find a story here, nor an enemy, or worlds filled with quests and collectables. There is however a scoring system based on the stunts you perform, and a leaderboard. The more dangerous your stunts, the more points you score.

[h1]My experience:[/h1]
I found that the more I practiced, the more fun I was having. As I soared through the mountains and did one ridiculous stunt after the other I experienced a nice flow. And adrenaline as well! There is something about soaring through a small hole in a mountain at incredible speed and suddenly having to make a sharp turn because of a wall you did not see and then nailing that move.

[h1]Controls:[/h1]
This is made possible because the controls are very good. To be fair, I noticed that I was a lot more accurate using a controller as it allows you to make smaller changes as opposed to the keyboard (and no mouse support as far as I know).

[h1]Dead ends:[/h1]
There is one gripe I would like to share. As said, the levels are randomly generated. Which means one world may not be as nice to fly through as another. What I found particularly unfair is that if you see an interesting spot to fly inside a mountain it could easily be that it is actually a dead end which means you crash and lose all points. Yes, there must be a sense of danger and risk involved, but if you go for a high score this demotivates from flying dangerously.

[h1]Technicalities:[/h1]
Technically the game ran perfectly fine. No loading times, not even between worlds. Controller support worked well, even though steam warns that the game is not optimized for it. I also played via Steam Link, also no problems.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
You get a great game for a low price which is fun to boot up every once in a while. Easy to learn, difficult to master. Consider this a nice break from the more complex games out there and just enjoy your flight.

You are given a procedurally generated landscape through which you guide your wingsuit-equipped avatar. The controls are limited to only steering with no button presses. The game is always exactly as difficult as you want it to be; there are no pre-defined goals or challenges. While there is ostensibly a leaderboard, you could easily fly around for 30 minutes just being a tourist and scoring no points. On the other hand, you could find a very challenging run through a level and crash 20 times attempting to master it. The fact that the game asks so little and offers so much is probably why I return to play even for a little while every few days.

38270304.review:
Lot of fun. The learning curve is quick and rewarding and you'll be doing awesome stunts within a few minutes. The procedurally generated maps are diverse and great and the simple concept and controls make it a very relaxing experience. 

The game can be about as hard or as easy as you want it to be. There is essentially no limit to the complexity of stunts you can pull off.

I do have one minor complaint: the ability to hold and build on your score from map to map is borderline cheating on the leaderboards. You are able to get some safe points, go through a portal, and repeat. There is no end to how long you can go at this and thus (if you're willing to grind for like an hour) you can break one million points pretty easily and get absurdly high on the leaderboard with no real skill or effort. The combo is a more legitimate measure as it stands now.

I also have some things I'd like to see (not all of which I'm sure are a good idea as they can taint the simple format):

1. First person
2. A mode where you can self propel and switch drections as fast as you can move your finger.
3. Peer to peer multiplayer.
4. (assuming its not there and I just haven't looked for it) A total of all the points you've gotten ever.

Really fun little game though, well made and balanced.

38252683.review:
beautiful game
easy gameplay controls that can be adjusted to your liking
atmospheric, realistic wind
global ranking, clear scoring

Honestly I'm new to Steam and the person who was supposed to be my Gandalf through my new gaming adventure left but I didn't want to close the account just because we broke up so I was determined to find my own games and have my own fun and I bought this game just because it was on sale and the screenshots looked cool.

With Superflight, I was faced with something I had never experienced before while gaming: pure, addicting, simple fun. There were no crazy boss fights, no tutorials to hold my hand, no sneaky agonizing puzzles or ridiculous AI chats, I was just a little wingsuit person floating around these crazy structures and if I managed to survive, I got points. The game only demands that you fly around, nothing else. If you fly really close to a structure, you get points. If you fly through a structure (some have arches, loops, holes in the walls, crevices etc) you get points. At first the controls are on default so you crash into everything and hate yourself, but after adjusting the sensitivity of each control (WASD only) you find that it's really easy to maneuver and go wherever you need to go. The game gives you 24 achievements you can unlock, and I don't know what it's like for other people, but my very first time running the game I was so excited to accomplish my first achievement that I sat myself down for five straight hours unlocking as much as I could. When you do crash into things, and you WILL crash into things, your score pops up along with your high score and your highest combo score and your world ranking. It's pretty neat to see your rank change, or well, it's pretty neat to me.

Regardless of what you usually play or what your skill level is, Superflight provides some good, quality fun and is a lovely game everyone should have in their library.

38246628.review:
What I like best about this game is that it knows what it is, and it does it perfectly. It's basically a game where you glide through a world of obsticles playing it as safe or a dangerous as you want- with more points being awarded to you for risky moves. You end up crashing a lot, which is fun, but it only takes half a second before you're back in the air to try again, and the more you do it, the better you get.

One of the aspects of the game that I really appreciate is that it has no music, just nice sound effects. So I typically load up some songs on youtube that I want to listen to and let it play in the background as I play the game- that works very well. The game also only requires one hand to play- so it's easy to just sit back, rest one hand on the arrow pads, and play like that- and there's never really a need to use the other hand. 

I've also tried this game using the Occulus Rift. I don't think it's made for this, but if you use something like Virtual Desktop, it will allow you to open and play the game in Virtual Desktop, and then you just enlarge the screen area in the VR until it's all you can see. Since the action in the game is almost always in the middle of the screen, this works well with VR- though it's still not as fully as immersive as if it was 360 degree. 

So if you're thinking about this game, definitely get it- it's fun and relaxing, and a great thing to do if you just want to chill and listen to some music in the background.

38190514.review:
This game is simply amazing. It's a great way to get your mind free and escape into a wonderful, endless world where your dreams of becoming a bird, spreading your wings and gliding away can finally come true. I have never played a game that delivers the sensation of flying so well as Superfly does.
I have absolutely nothing bad to say about the game. The worlds look gorgeous and mysterious, the animations are fluid and the controls are very responsive. You have a lot of options to play around with to tailor your experience and make the game suit your playstyle and hardware. Also: The price is more than fair!

There are still a few things I would like to see in the future:

-Character models (maybe unlockables after reaching a certain score) that are a little more aerodynamic. Maybe even an editor, where you can pick colors, hats, trails or wingsuits.
-A coop mode, where you can glide along with your friends (optionally with and without collision).
-A little more freedom when it comes to movement. Barrel rolls (maybe by pressing Q and E), holding your character sideways at the cost of dropping quicker (could be realized by repeatidly tapping Q or E), the ability to fly loopings and combine them with the before mentioned barrel rolls.
-The camera is a little shaky at times, which really doesn't play well with my motion sickness. It would be great if one could turn off the camera shake, especially when flying close to objects and it starts to count the score.

Obviously you can not expect the developer to update the game, as it doesn't sit at a high price point nor is it declared as early access, beta or alpha. Still, I would love to see some features added in the future to keep the game a little more interesting and engaging. Although it would certainly take away from the simplicity of the game.

Right now, I already love it and it has already made it into my "Favorites" category in Steam.
Thank you so much for making this game!

EDIT: I loved that when I entered my gamertag as a seed in the map generator, the world was completely black and white! :D

38177080.review:
就一个字，特别舒服!
玩了很多游戏都觉得没有写评测的必要，但是这个游戏我玩了整整7分钟，忍不住要来推荐一下了（自认为已经玩透了）
-玩法简单有深度
玩法简单到可以一句话概括（控制一只鸟人在一个有重力的世界里避免撞到障碍物并获得尽可能高的分数），而它的深度体现在：游戏一开始玩家就面临一个抉择：是“选择沿着障碍物滑翔获得较低的得分”或是“飞入障碍物的空隙赢取较高的得分”，前一种选择较为安逸，但是潜在的隐患就是要获得和第二种方式一样的得分需要花费多得多的时间，所谓夜长梦多，对目标是超高分的玩家来说未必真的稳妥；后一种选择是我情感上比较偏向的可能也是制作者鼓励的一种游戏方式：放飞自我，挑战风险，老子就是要在这世界里自由翱翔，穿过障碍物的空隙的时候不仅得分数字刷得飞快，手柄的震感也能模拟进入空隙那一瞬间的风压变化，至少对于我来说，我感受到了所谓“速度”（真的，老子玩了十几年游戏了还没有这么爽过，极品飞车GTA满速都没有）继续说它的深度:除去游玩策略方面有深度外，操作方面，对于没有尝试过飞行模拟类的游戏玩家来说，摇杆前推俯冲，摇杆后拉抬升这种操作模式很反人类，没有接触过的朋友需要花一小段时间来适应，等到大家适应了这种操作，你慢慢会发现鸟人有两个基本指标：1最简单的速度2倾角，那么过空隙这一挑战就简化成了“通过爬升减速俯冲加速来把鸟人的速度调整在一个合理的区间”以及“调整俯仰角来迎合空隙的长度”，对这两个技巧的巧妙运用，是得分的关键,也是游戏里仅有的具有操作难度的技巧。
-反馈到位
不少游戏有反馈不及时反馈不全各种毛病，这方面superflight做得挺好的（不是非常不错 也不是无敌，只是一个挺好）过洞时呼啸的风，贴地飞行疯涨的分，音效也好，UI也好，包括震动也好，都恰到好处，让我想起了去年刚接触守望先锋爆头的那种爽快感，就连鸟人撞上障碍物的骨折也是打击感十足
-我实在TM编不出来了，对了上面也是我编的
这只是一个小游戏，售价十五，物超所值，主要是它让我想起来小时候的一些梦了，孩子都爱飞，我知道有的人能在梦里飞起来但我不能，这款游戏多多少少给了我一点感动，也让我想起来之前高中的时候，晚上夜巡的老师走之后才敢偷偷拿出PSP玩一会儿王牌空战的那些日子

Qui n'a jamais eu envie de prolonger à l'infini la scène de la fuite de la caverne aux merveilles d'Aladdin à l'aide du tapis volant ?
Superflight fait partie de ces "petits jeux" au concept puissant qui vous font dire : "après cette run, promis j'arrête", bien que vous ayez prononcé cette phrase, pour la première fois, une heure et demi auparavant !
Sobre, fun, parfois grandiose, malgré l'étonnante simplicité des environnements générés procéduralement. On aura tôt fait de sauvegarder ses petits préférés, piochées au hasard dans une palette de possibilités presque infinies, allant du quasi-naturel au totalement surréaliste.
L'une des meilleures découvertes de 2017, selon moi.

38008427.review:
This game is so amazing. It's so simple of a concept but executed masterfully. You fly down, through and around procedurally generated floating mountains or islands scoring points by taking risks and staying alive.

The control in this game (with xbox 360 controller) is fantastic and very responsive. You only really use the analog stick when flying and it works so well. I tried wasd and it seemed pretty good too but I prefer the controller with this game for sure.

There is no music and you just hear wind but with this game if you have other music it's great to turn on in the background and just fly around listening while trying to break your old high score.

First Impressions / Gameplay
https://youtu.be/uqWYxNxsTPQ

You can create custom seed worlds and they really neat. I found 2 really cool ones, try creating one with just 2 blank spaces and press enter, and the other is my name Skid Row Trash it has cool pink pillars.

You can save the levels so you can replay them, however, the level browser sucks and the more levels you have the longer it takes and harder it is to find what you are looking for. Also it seems to save levels even if you don't request it to which is kind of annoying because then you have to go in and delete them and constantly clean up the save map area.

The other thing I wish there was is a new world button or option in the pause menu to save time.

Other than that, this is absolutely amazing. I highly recommend it. It's a great high score game with leaderboards and it is so replayable it reminds me of the old Tony Hawk days when you would constantly restart as soon as you screw up so you can go for that huge score.

38007511.review:
Superflight is a tremendously good game for the money. Simple rules, great control feel, elegant graphical design, and well crafted procedural generation all blend into an experience that shifts effortlessly between tranquil enjoyment and breathtaking shows of agility. Will you play for hundreds of hours? I doubt it. But you will enjoy it while you play it and it's the price of a cup of coffee.

I have a few minor grumbles: the scoring sound effect is jaringly harsh against the otherwise naturalistic setting, the way you move between levels when you drop off the bottom is clunky (I'd have like to see it going on forever), and the way the game hurries you on to new levels shows off the procedural generation but actually takes away from the greatest joy of the game which is mastering routes through a single level.

Gripes aside this is an elegant demonstration of how games don't have to be complex to be good. I liked it so much I gifted copies to two friends.

38006449.review: A great little game, simple and fun: the small asking price is about right. I would love it if they added multiplayer and there is no music (at time of writing) so set yourself up with a good playlist and then relax to your tunes while you fly. It's a great pick up and play game a refreshing change from so many games with over complex systems for far less fun. There is no reason not to buy this game at this price and there are sure to be lots of you tube videos and streams of people playing it.

37996292.review:
Responsive controls. Minimalist and beautiful low-poly graphics. Suitable for relaxists and score chasers alike. It's easy to get all achievements (if that matters to you). There's no background music, just sound effects, but it works well this way.

My level of engagement varied a bit while playing, particularly because due to procedural generation some maps were much more fun than others, but I did play a couple of maps over and over and over again to get some sections right and explore the better routes to get higher scores, which I see as a healthy addiction and another reason to recommend the game.

Perhaps I would stick with it longer if it had more gameplay mechanics (it could borrow some from AaAaAA!!! - A Reckless Disregard for Gravity), but I understand Superflight is simple by design and that's part of why it appeals to so many people, so I'm grateful to have played it, will keep it installed and play it further :-).

A multiplayer mode (or even ghosts) could be awesome as well.

37969092.review:
Superflight achieves some kind of Platonic ideal. Simple inputs give you just enough control to feel confident in success and responsible for failure, while the air, feeling tangible and roaring through your ears, buffets your avatar this way and that like real wind might. It's just this side of unpredictable, but feels fair. It'll take seconds to learn, but who knows how long to master?

Hair-raising near-misses with the wind screaming at you suddenly give way to open air and a gentle breeze, and then another plunge, twisting through the ether, as your score ratchets up with satisfying clinks. Then you crash! And are back at it in a moment, correcting your last course, aiming for that portal you saw earlier. Through a rocky window you shoot -- Close Call! The portal is below. You dive steeply and blast through it -- and a new world beckons.

Use the Steam Overlay to play your music of choice in the background. You're not flying, you're falling...with style.

37969038.review: A fun, relaxing game. I would love to have this on my phone at some point.

37967267.review:
So, I really like this game - get ready for gushing.

Given that flight is such a universally desired ability, I've always been surprised at how infrequently it appears in games. But behold - GrizzlyGames has delivered that sensation of freedom, exploration, and adrenaline that we imagine flying to be. The minimalistic and responsive controls create a perfect balance of easy to start but difficult to master. 

While the maps may first appear to just be randomly colored and arranged blocks, you begin to notice deliberate palettes and topography that reward and support you staying airborne beyond your score.

"Zen mode" is perfectly titled and a greatly appreciated inclusion. Though I think making the character indestructible in this mode would enhance the carefree feeling even more. Saving maps is also a fantastic bonus, but an option to fly between them like a playlist would be superb.

In all, this game is worth well more than it's price. Thank you GrizzlyGames for making it.

37940634.review:
I haven't played this game for long, but to be fair there isn't really that much to this game. After ten minutes of play, you are fully qualified to review it.

This is a quaint, simplistic game that is well worth the £2.09 asking price in the UK. I don't mind paying £2.09 for a simplistic game because it puts money in the pocket of indie developers who may one day produce an awesome game because of the money they raised with this game.

The game isn't going to win awards in the graphics department, but the graphics are fine for this type of game. The gameplay is repetitive, but the whole point is to try and beat your previous score - it needs to be repetitive (and the maps need to be generated identically to the previous run, which this game does).

My only complaint is the leaderboard ranking. Nice touch, but it seems like it is "comparing apples to oranges". If I have a map that is really easy to navigate and someone else has a difficult map, his/her score of 10000 is well-earned while mine is not. If there isn't a way to turn the global ranking off, I would suggest this would be a nice feature.

My wishlist has two items:

1) The ability to do a loop-the-loop. I'm no expert in this type of flying, so I don't know if a real-life flight would support a loop-the-loop... but nevertheless, the ability to loop-the-loop would be brilliant.
2) The ability to "streamline" yourself (bring your arms in) so that you can dive downwards faster.

I like this game. I hope the developers do more with it.

37933847.review:
[h1] Short Review [/h1]
SuperFlight is an amazing game that has great atmophere while keeping the randomly generated levels cool and unique. [b] I highly recommend this game! [/b]

[h1] Long review [/h1]
Like I said in the short review, great atmophere and great level generation. the attention to detail is great too, like whenever you get near a bunch of large objects, the overall sound gets loud and booming. 
      The controls are simple and give you a good sense of your flight speed and overall contol. Options also allow you to set the sensitivity of your horizontal and/or virtical movement, as well as contoler support.
      A highscore rankings board can keep you trying to take risks flying though tight spots. Whether you be going for a world record or just a personal one, you'll be wanting to get that trick flight just right. (Just one more try...Just one more try...) [i] Not into highscores?[/i] No problem! Just turn on Zen mode and you no longer have to worry about a little ticking noise keeping track of a highscore you don't care about.
      The game has no music (which really helps with the calming portian of the game), but you could play tense music to make getting a highscore more enjoyable.
[b] All and all, it's an amazing game, and so worth the cheap prise! I highly recommend this Superflight! [/b]

37758319.review:
Superflight is an achievement in beauty through simplicity in both visuals and gameplay.
For the low price, you can't go wrong.

The concept is easy to grasp. You're presented with a large randomized floating landscape, and the more risks you take while gliding through it (near misses, holes, caves, wall proximity, and the score multiplier goes up the longer you sustain this risky behavior), the more points you get. You can fly into portals or off the edge of the map to reach new areas that are generated on-the-fly with all sorts of crazy shapes and color schemes. Keep going until you crash! Trying to beat your high score is exciting without being frustrating, and those rare moments where you pull off amazing stunts are so damn satisfying.
It's just like the feeling of finding legendary loot in a big RPG. "Hell yeah, that just happened."
As a bonus, if you see a level you like while exploring, you can save it for later and share it!

Controls are smooth, runs great, developer is diligent at fixing stuff. No complaints.
Superflight is too simple to have any major flaws, and that's why it's so damn brilliant.

Side note: Play this game on drugs. It's so good.
Put on your favorite music and just let this game take you.

37670133.review:
[h1]This little gem is one of the most promising games of 2017![/h1]

[b]Gameplay and Comparison[/b]
Superflight is construced around a very simple idea: perfom close fly-bys and awesome stunts in a wingsuit while falling from the sky at breakneck speed. GrizzlyGames managed to polish this concept and develop a timeless and well functioning game that can be played over and over again. Superflight combines intuitive controls with the power of procedurally generated levels.
Many indie games I've come across lately suffer from some kind of childhood diseases: Either they're repetitive, buggy, not intuitive or boring. Superflight however is the perfect match - it feels sleek, fast paced and all in all just well thought-out.

[b]What I Really Liked:[/b]
[list]
    [*]very intuitive controls and physics
    [*]pleasing art-sytle, modern but yet timeless
    [*]procedurally genereated levels for endless fun
    [*]bug-free experience, it just works
    [*]good performance
[/list]

[b]A Big Plus:[/b]
The game features some very well made achievements which are demanding but manageable to get.

[b]My Conclusion:[/b]
Superflight is a fun game and an excellent example of pure gameplay - no clutter. I can only recommend getting this underrated gem straightaway! $2,99 is a ridiculously low price for such a masterpiece that promises some good hours of fun.

[i]Thank you GrizzlyGames, I hope to see more from you in the future! [/i]

37630652.review:
There is so much to be said about the potential this game could achieve. Right from the start I was hooked. The controls are easy to pick up and the infinitly unique maps can really start to make you lose track of time. The scoring system is rewarding and the things you discover within each map are exciting and often challenging. You can even create your own map by typing in phrases, words, and gibberish (typing as many capital A's as possible creates a pretty sick looking map).

All of that being said, there is so much more that can be done with the game. Zen mode is alright, map creation is often humorous, and the leaderboards for largest scoring run/ combo and highest overall score can certainly push you to the limits of your competitive nature. But thats it. Nothing else has been added and I know that after a certain amount of time it will start to feel repetitive (I'm already sort of at this point), which is why I'm hoping that the development team will take as many steps forward as they can starting with different game modes. A couple of ideas my friend and I had in mind are as follows: 

1. Trailing or being able to follow a Bot or a Friends run through a set map with varying difficulty.
2. Some sort of obstacle course where you have to fly through set checkpoints until you reach the end (again with scaling difficulty).
3. Multiplayer/ Online play would be awesome specifically for races (maybe with special powerups to help or deter your opponents?) but I realize that takes some time to work out.

At the moment, the game feels limited, so much more could be added to SuperFlight and I hope that certain things will be added in the coming months. I would still recommend this game because even in its very early stages, the mechanics and physics are sound and I havent encountered a single bug or glitch. Its a great time waster and an essential addition to your steam library.

 Children gaze open mouthed,
 Taken by surprise;
 Nobody down below  Believes their eyes.

We're surfing in the air,
We're swimming in the frozen sky,
We're drifting over icy
 Mountains floating by.

 Suddenly swooping low
On an ocean deep,
 Rousing up a mighty monster
From his sleep.

We're walking in the air,
We're dancing in the midnight sky

37557199.review:
This is a great and relaxing wingsuit flight simulator with no pressure to accomplish anything like checkpoints or time attacks. You can take it at your own pace, find the parts of the game you enjoy and just play. There is no combat, alien invasions or zombies. Your goal is to just fly. How and where is up to you.

It is a third person flight simulator with randomly generated maps. Each map is a 3D island full of holes, passages and cliff faces for you to fly along, under, in and through. You want to go at speed, just look down and plummet away. This can make your suit a little unresponsive though - gravity and aerodynamics are like that... You want to chill, enter 'Zen mode' and glide along. You can reset any map whenever you choose, change maps or save them for replaying/sharing (plenty of interesting ones suggested in the forums). Really basic in terms of refined graphics, audio, etc. Really well developed in terms of gameplay important matter, like physics and responsive controls.

Positive:
[list]
[*] Smooth gamplay that can played at your own pace.
[*] The level generator is spot on. 
[*] Controls are easy to use.
[*] The physics system is well developed.
[*] Achievements are easily obtained and fun to try for.
[/list]
Negative:
[list]
[*] Some players may dislike the lack of direction in game.
[/list]
Conclusion:

Know what you are getting here. It is a simulation that is there for you to switch on and forget about the stresses of the real world. There are no real objectives beyond 'Do not crash'. This can either make you feel like a lack of accomplishment after playing for a while or a need to try just one more level. Good value for the price. You won't play it every day for hours, but you will come back to it in the future.

37556993.review:
[b]Yeah, it's good and worth the small asking price.[/b] With all the top-notch praise, I was hoping for something just *slightly* deeper and more engaging, but hey, this works too.

[i]Essentially, you are thrown into a randomly created level (which is tower-shaped) and are paragliding towards the bottom grabbing as many points as you can along the way.[/i] You aren't really [i]flying[/i] because it's pretty much just descending down for the most part. There are portals you can go into that take you into another level and you carry over your score. Combos are a thing, too.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+A nice little score chasing game that is well worth the asking price
+Has that 'one more run' appeal, but play sessions tend to be quite short
+Only the controller stick is really needed
+The artwork is quite neat and I love how the different levels have really colorful layouts

[b]Cons:[/b]
-What you see is what you get; there isn't much depth to this, and in some ways it feels more like a proof-of-concept to some larger game with more bells-and-whistles

[b]Yeah, I totally recommend this game.[/b] Just don't expect anything too crazy or in-depth.

37520279.review:
The single, best option you have for understanding what this game is like is to simply watch the first video. The devs lay out the entire game—all its options, controls, actions, and goals—in that 3 minute video. There's almost nothing else to it. No mulitplayer, no shooting, no competitive modes, no raceing, no running from the deep psychological monsters of your childhood.

Just gliding without smashing your little voxel head on the rocks. Swing around a procedurally-generated, floating mountain. Gain points. Fly more daringly, gain more points. Zip through a tiny opening. Gain even more points. Fly thorough a wide opening, zip around a vertical canyon, get boxed-in and smash into the wall at mach 2. Lose outrageous amount of accumulating points. Feel the pain.

Click and do it again.

It's a neat game. If you're looking for something that feels like a filler, but is likely to suck up your whole afternoon, Superflight is it.

37239765.review:
As I write this, I've only played Superflight for half an hour.  I only intended to play it for 5-10 minutes to try it out.  The game is incredibly simple.  The graphics are earthy toned geometric blocks.  Your man in a wingsuit is made of blocks.  The map is made of blocks.  When you crash - and you will crash - you explode into all of your little blocks.

The entirety of the game boils down to a score attack.  There's no time limit.  There's no metric that dictates how aggressive or how careful you have to be.  I already find myself being aggressive earlier in runs, then being more selective with my angles as I realize I'm approaching my high score... and then aggressive again when I feel like I'm running out of focus (It's easy to forget to blink) to try and land a big combo or two before I disintegrate into a rock wall.

As best I can tell, a round can go on forever.  You start off in an area descending towards a random collection of walls, plateaus, tunnels and ledges.  As you descend further and further (it is a wingsuit game, you can't just fly at top speed in any direction like Superman) eventually you will start to see portals (pink blocks swirling around together) and/or start to blackout as you descend to the bottom of the map.  If you take the portal, you gain 1000 points and fall into a new area.  If you simply blackout, you continue into another area at the same angle and velocity you left the last area with.

The game rewards you with more points, higher multipliers and aggression bonuses depending upon your risk-taking.  Flying really close to a wall for 10 seconds might net you 1500 points if you're very snug.  In comparison, shooting for a wingsuit-tiny vertical gap at high speed with walls on every side might net you 15000 or more if you make it.  You can score in giant, satisfying bunches or slow, calculated manuevers.

When you crash - again, you will crash - you are presented with your final score for the flight, your top score of all time (along with that score's world ranking) and your top combo of all time (along with a ranking, again).

It is simple.  It is beautiful.  You can play this game like a Red Bull athlete with a deathwish, shooting for every tiny gap you can find, blind to what is on the other side.  You can play this game with a relaxed attitude, floating here and there, always staying in your comfort zone, making a flight last - well - probably as long as you wanted to.

This game accomplishes exactly what it was designed to accomplish and comes from a team of three people.  It is easily worth the full $3 dollar price-tag.  In half an hour, it has made me smile, laugh and gasp.  I cannot recommend it highly enough.

Superflight is excellent short-term fun for whenever you need a break from... well, everything. Sometimes I don't want to shoot or read or think or analyze the HUDs, enemy behaviour or placements. Sometimes I just want to relax. Superflight offers enough opportunity for it. 

From my early childhood onwards, flying has always been my dream, so buying Superflight straight away was kind of a no-brainer. And it's an excellent experience of getting closer to flying with its tight controls and colorful worlds full of wondrous shapes,  Frankly, I can also get a little closer to the very real possiblity of falling and crashing and dying without really having to fly.

If you don't just want to relax, you can also play for glory: namely, for the highest score. I'm usually not a fan of highscore-driven games. Achievements motivate me more than online leaderboards. But getting a nice long combo on Superflight is motivating, because of the multiplyier the game offers. Seeing the numbers go up continously is just so addicting. And finding a map you can train on, one that compliments your own flight style, is just so, so rewarding.

The only thing the game is missing is a soundtrack, which doesn't really bother me, because I like to listen to my own music during the game. It would just be nice to have.

37135476.review:
Put on your favourite tunes, kick back, and fly through infinite procedurally generated landscapes

Sometimes it pays to keep things simple. Get points by flying close to the terrain. Generate multipliers by uninterrupted close flight. The game records your high score and shows how you rank worldwide. That's it.

But who cares about points? Check the Zen Mode checkbox in settings and they disappear from the screen (points still get counted and high scores recorded). Fly just for the pleasure of it and relax.

There's no soundtrack, just the whistling of the wind. The ticking sound of points being scored and special effects were annoying to me so I turned them off.

The procedurally generated landscapes are beautiful and varied in palette and structure. The structure makes a big difference as to how you fly: some suit a shallow floaty approach where as others encourage hair raising fast dives through vertical gaps. As in Minecraft, you can create your own seeds, save the seeds of maps you like and share them with others.

Recommended for fans of wing suit flying games, fans of procedural generation and those prepared to risk the price of a cup of coffee on a simple yet high quality game.

I love the fact that each seed is unique, and that they will produce the same results on any computer. 

This game runs like a dream, even with a graphics card that is way below min spec.

So, if you have $2.99 left over in your steam wallet, or want to buy a simple and relaxing game with almost infinite replayability... Superflight is your answer.

This game has charmed it's way deep into my heart. With such a tiny price it was probably only going to be given a slim chance of winning me over before I considered my money's worth to have been had and the game then disposed of. Sure enough, I played it for 15 minutes and walked away convinced it "needed more structure" and "some sort of objectives and hand-crafted levels". After all, so many games think random world generation is a shortctu to free fun when it really isn't. I left that first session thinking... "nicely executed but it needs MORE to it". Yet I was so wrong.

Something made me come back to it and I leared to play differently. I stopped overthinking it and instead decided to just chill out within it's blocky worlds. To cruise the spires and casually scan for interesting nooks and crannies to invade before shifting gears to hi-octane, snaking through my improvised goal and then punching out the other side with a huge grin of self-made satisfaction. The physics are perfectly tuned and the controls simplified enough to let your brain happily sail through on instinctive flightpaths and snap judgements.

Don't think of this as a game. Ignore the achievements and discard the importance of score. Just cruise it's landscapes and dial up the challenge "on the fly". If you'll pardon the pun. Stop caring and just escape into an endless balance of calm chaos all under your mind's control.

Love it.

A simple, stylish, easy to learn but difficult to master, quick-play adrenaline rush? Yes please!

The concept is simple: Glide dangerously close to technicolor rock formations to rack up as many points as possible before you inevitably crash and end your run. The more dangerously close you get to smacking into the mountains, the bigger the points. Do you play it safe skimming around the exterior walls of each formation? Or do you recklessly dive into the heart of the formation and whip through tight tunnels and hope you don't find a dead end? For a paltry $3 bucks, you get a great little time-waster that you can play a quick 5 minute session or an hourlong quest to beat your previous high score. The graphics are simplistic, but what it lacks in visual detail it makes up for in style and a very viceral sense of speed. The controls and the wingsuit physics are solid. 

Definitely recommend, especially for such a itty bitty price tag!

36856612.review:
This game is exactly what it says on the packet. A largely relaxing experience gliding around giant coloured monoliths. It's an unapologetically casual game for when you are looking for a bit of quick escapism without much thought required in a break between sessions of Path of Exile or just before bed.

Scoring is based on how close you can fly to the monoliths and for how long you can maintain that without crashing. Extra points are awarded for proximity to monoliths on more than one side. For example, flying through a tight valley might give you 2x points while flying through a small tunnel might give you 4x points for proximity on 4 sides. (These multipliers are arbitrary, I have no idea of the actual math here.)

You’re not forced to fly close to anything either. If you’ve just been though an intense tunnel experience you can simply glide outside the range of anything risky for a bit until you compose yourself again for your next daredevil stunt. Or you can glide from one map to the next and enjoy the view if that’s your thing.

Still, the scoring mechanism adds some interest and I suspect that for most players the game would get old pretty quickly without it. Scoring also gives you some incentive to return to revisit your previous best and to push your luck enough that you’re probably going to die sooner rather than later, and that’s a good thing.

Is it a well done game? Yes. Is it worth $3? It's pretty disposable really, and no doubt will appear in a great many bundles in a year or two, but it's an indulgent purchase for less than the cost of a cup of coffee; you could do a lot worse.

36757043.review:
Ein kleines, feines und günstiges Wingsuit-Spiel, welches gerade durch seine Einfachheit überzeugt.

Prinzipiell ist der Spielablauf sehr einfach. Man fliegt/gleitet durch die Level und versucht so nah wie möglich an die Felsen zu fliegen um Punkte zu bekommen. Richtig interessant wird es, wenn man gezielt auf Highscore spielt und jede noch so enge Spalte versucht erfolgreich zu passieren. Es handelt sich dabei zum Teil um Try and Error, um die perfekte Route zu finden und sie auch wirklich mit Höchstpunktzahl zu schaffen.

Es ist zwar kein Spiel was einen kompletten Abend füllen wird, aber man spielt es immer mal wieder für 10-15 Minuten und hat einfach unkomplizierten Spaß. Gerade für den Preis lohnt es sich sehr.


Die Entwickler sind ein (glaube ich) kleines dreiköpfiges Team von Studenten, die das Spiel auch weiter optimieren und sehr ehrlich mit den Spielern umgehen. Sie versprechen einem nicht das Blaue vom Himmel, sondern gehen ehrlich und offen mit Bugs (gibt es kaum welche bzw. ich habe noch keine wrklich bemerkt), Schwierigkeiten und Entwicklungszielen um. Findet man heute eher selten, weshalb ich es noch positiv hervorheben möchte.

This game is...amazing, breathtaking, relaxing. It is so many things and takes you to another world where you can bask in the beauty of the environments. Sure there is a highscore element, but playing in Zen Mode can hide the score to give you  a more cinematic experience.
I played a single run for five minutes just soaring from map to map, enjoying the wind rushing past each time I flew close and then pulling away wuth great speed and force just to glide back again into another portal. The game is so therapeutic, it really does take you to where your mind can run free and forget about the troubles of the world, if only for a few seconds.
Sure you could play this game for the biggest high score or the tightest turns or dodging through the narowest gap, but there are plenty of games that play off high scores. They are all fun, but no game gives you such a cinematic experience along the way and this game really pulls it off.

36686396.review:
This kind of should be the new 'flappybird' when I'm honest. But with higher production values and more interesting physics within. The procedural level generation is topnotch for a game of this type, the controls are good, decent learning curve and plenty of opportunity for some crazy flying and true mastery. It reminds me of AaaaAaAa for the Awesome, another wingsuit high speed indie game, which already was a great game using a similar concept... except this game just goes on and on and on forever with new levels every transition (either through a portal with a 1000 point bonus or by falling 'through the ground' at which point a new level appears), which is superb. Of course, when you die, you restart in the last world that was generated. 
For it's price this game is going to be excellent bang for the buck. Even if you only play one hour, this game has the potential to lure you back in, keep you hooked for months trying to beat the online leadboards. IF you get a kick out of high speed games in general, moving just right, past deep pillars, through tight corridors, following down breathtaking depths like the many wingsuit daredevil videos you can find on the YouTubes, then this game is totally for you!! 
Honestly, I kind of wish this game had a tricks system of some sort or more opportunity for bonus scores. I mean it might feel out of place for a game this abstract or stylised, but it could be a neat way of creating much longer combos. At the moment we're kind of dependent on what the procedural level generation provides us with (most notably passing through the tightest corridors seems to provide the highest bonus scores). 
If there's one critique possible for a game of this type, it is how sometimes lining up for a perfect soar through a window shape rock gives you more points, than pulling of that crazy turn and recovery, steering away from the rocks in the nick of time, whilst also continuing your run downwards at very high speeds. I think a reasonable argument can be made the scoring system for 'tricky manouvres' could have been taking more advanced flying into account.
Either way, this game is an easy 9.5 out 10. It's fun, it's cheap and it's replay value seems to be great.

36674824.review:
This is fantastic. The three students who made this deserve all the praise they've been getting.

Much like Dejoban's "AaAaAA!!! – A Reckless Disregard for Gravity" series, this is a "falling simulator," where you have a limited availability to navigate around things in your path, you get points for doing this by getting particularly close to things, and bonuses for navigating particularly tricky gaps and running up points continually for period of time.

Unlike AaAaAA!!, there are no cheering/booing fans, there aren't glowing bonuses scattered everywhere or on particularly challenging paths, the levels weren't exactly 'designed' by anyone (although you can play any level you like over and over), and you never have to land. There's also no music but the wind, you're more gliding than falling, and you could potentially play one single game forever without dying and without seeing the same level twice. You can also turn on "Zen mode," which turns off the point indicators, so you can just soar around and fall without pressure.

Each level has a randomly chosen "seed" of characters to "name" the level, and that seed is used by the game's algorithm to generate the level. Any specific seed will generate the same level each time, so can also use this seed to share levels with people, or create your own by entering a name, birthday, mashing on the keyboard, whatever. You don't design the level, per se, the game's math does that for you, but it can make it easier to remember and share.

When you get to the bottom of a level, fly to the edge, or fly through one of the not-exactly-randomly placed portals, it takes you to a new level. There are potentially an infinite number of levels, even changing or adding/removing one single character means a whole new, sometimes very different, level. I haven't found a bad one yet.

10/10, will crash again.

Amazing and addicting! I love it.

 I kinda wish there was an explore mode where you just fly through several levels looking at the scenery but that's just me.

Pros:
+Simple controls
+No overly complex things
+Calming. This isn't a 'simulator' or 'puzzle game' that was advertised as something relaxing and fun and ended up not being so, it really is relaxing and fun.
+Nice graphics, the scenery is beautiful and fantasy-like. If you're a Steven Universe fan you may see a Malachite or Alexandrite like color scheme in some levels, it's a nice feeling.
+For me, it works very well and doesn't lag.
+The controls, again are easy and you're able to adjust the sensitivity. If you press buttons quite forcefully, a low sensitivity level may be ideal.

Cons:
-No music or option to have music...yeah that's it. 

This game is near flawless when it comes to non-combat, non-horror, etc games/simulators and I love it. I don't see many that are truly casual in my eyes. This is truly refreshing.

Remember back in the day.....

When flash games were all the rage? Back when MMOs weren't a thing.

Well lemme tell you this. This game, Superflight, brings back the fun that was associated with flash games. The simple concept of a game being there just to kill time and have some fun.

Now I watched Jacksepticeye play it and I could tell you I was trying to hold on to my desk. Just moving so fast and dodging things while also racking up a score for doing daring things like going through holes. It can give you an adrenaline rush. I checked it out and found it to be CHEAP....AS IN MONEY CHEAP. ~$3 CHEAP.

This game even does what minecraft does and creates the maps randomly! No two maps are the same! You can even enter your name in to use as a "Seed". A seed is basically the maps DNA. So if you find a seed that is awesome you can share it with others!

Its Easy to Learn and Hard to master but you can have so much fun playing it and challenging yourself.
PEOPLE. BUY. THIS. GAME.
